result.execSummary:
The defendant Charles C. Miller was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Charles C. Miller is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges.

  • Charles C. Miller was found guilty of Possession of Narcotic Drugs, a class I felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(3g)(am).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

miscConds.notes: If probation or extended supervision is revoked or discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant and in favor of restitution victims and governmental entities for the balance due.  Collections may include income assignment.  This applies to all counts and financial obligations.

Obey all of the rules and regulations of supervising probation agent.
*  Pay supervision fees.
Do not possess or consume alcoholic beverages and do not have alcoholic beverages within the residence.  Do not be in taverns or on any premises licensed for the sale of intoxicating beverages, except restaurants or grocery stores.  Do not possess or consume controlled substances, except by prescription.  Submit voluntarily to random tests of blood, breath or urine.  Participate in counseling deemed appropriate by your agent, which may include: alcohol/drug, anger management/DV counseling, psychiatric/psychological, AODA Assessment and follow-through with recommended treatment.  Actively search for employment, be employed or attend an educational institution or vocational training program.
*  Pay fine of $500.00 and court costs including all applicable surcharges.
*  If unpaid financial obligations remain at discharge or revocation, civil judgment to be entered.
*  Defendant is ordered to submit to a DNA sample & pay DNA surcharge and notice is given.
Spend 60 days in the county jail, commencing 4/9/16 @ 8am.  Huber privileges are allowed.  Credit for 2 days served.  Perform 80 hours of community service for a public agency or a nonprofit charitable organization.  May not possess any weapons, including firearms.
May not possess any weapons, including firearms.

timeConds.notes: Huber and work crew authorized.  Credit for 2 days served.

Attorney Tracey Braun appeared for the State.  Defendant appears in person pro se.  Agent Erin Angel appears in person.  Clerk/S. Garcia.  The defendant has completed the 80 hours of community service and has not had any probation violations.  The state does not object to the petition for early discharge of probation.  The court grants the petition for petition of early discharge from probation effective today.  Order signed by the court.

records.descr: Notice and acknowledge of def voting ineligibility

records.addlTxt:
Attorney Margaret Drees appeared for the State. Defendant, Charles C. Miller, appeared with Attorney William Paul Michel.  Clerk: PT
Case is resolved.  Count 1 - DE pleads Guilty; found guilty by the court.  Count 2 - Dismissed by the State.  PSI is waived by parties and sentencing arguments made.  Defendant is ordered to submit to a DNA sample & pay DNA surcharge and notice is given.  Sentence is withheld and DE is placed on probation for 2 years with conditions.  As a condition court imposes 60 days in the KCJ commencing on 4/9/16 at 8:00 AM with Credit for 2 days.  Huber & Work Crew authorized.   Court imposes a fine of $500 plus costs & surcharge.  Cash Bond on deposit is to be applied and if any unpaid financial obligations remain at discharge or revocation, civil judgment to be entered.  DE is also ordered to complete 80 hours of community service.  Appeal Rights, Firearm Warning & Voting Acknowledgement given.
